title: Joshua Chapter 24 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 24 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 24 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 24.

questions.question: Where did Joshua gather all the tribes of Israel?
options: Shechem
Jericho
Mount Ephraim
Timnathserah
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem
questions.explanation: Joshua gathered all the tribes of Israel at Shechem as stated in Joshua 24:1.

questions.question: Who was Abraham's father mentioned in Joshua's speech?
options: Terah
Nachor
Isaac
Jacob
questions.correctAnswer: Terah
questions.explanation: Joshua mentions Terah as the father of Abraham in Joshua 24:2.

questions.question: What land did God lead Abraham through according to Joshua 24:3?
options: Canaan
Egypt
Mount Seir
Jordan
questions.correctAnswer: Canaan
questions.explanation: God took Abraham and led him throughout all the land of Canaan as stated in Joshua 24:3.

questions.question: To whom did God give Mount Seir?
options: Esau
Jacob
Isaac
Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Esau
questions.explanation: God gave Mount Seir to Esau as mentioned in Joshua 24:4.

questions.question: Who did God send to plague Egypt?
options: Moses and Aaron
Joshua and Caleb
Abraham and Isaac
Jacob and Esau
questions.correctAnswer: Moses and Aaron
questions.explanation: God sent Moses and Aaron to plague Egypt according to Joshua 24:5.

questions.question: What did God put between Israel and the Egyptians at the Red Sea?
options: Darkness
Fire
Water
Cloud
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness
questions.explanation: God put darkness between Israel and the Egyptians as described in Joshua 24:7.

questions.question: Who was the king of Moab that warred against Israel?
options: Balak
Balaam
Phinehas
Zippor
questions.correctAnswer: Balak
questions.explanation: Balak, son of Zippor, king of Moab, arose to war against Israel according to Joshua 24:9.

questions.question: Who did Balak send to curse Israel?
options: Balaam
Aaron
Joshua
Eleazar
questions.correctAnswer: Balaam
questions.explanation: Balak sent Balaam son of Beor to curse Israel as mentioned in Joshua 24:9.

questions.question: What did Balaam do instead of cursing Israel?
options: He blessed them
He cursed them
He fled
He was silent
questions.correctAnswer: He blessed them
questions.explanation: Balaam did not curse Israel but blessed them instead, as stated in Joshua 24:10.

questions.question: What did God send before Israel to drive out the two kings of the Amorites?
options: Hornets
Fire
Angels
Water
questions.correctAnswer: Hornets
questions.explanation: God sent hornets before Israel to drive out the two kings of the Amorites according to Joshua 24:12.

questions.question: According to Joshua 24:15, what is Joshua's declaration about whom he and his house will serve?
options: The LORD
The gods of the Amorites
The gods of their fathers
No one
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Joshua declared that he and his house will serve the LORD as stated in Joshua 24:15.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua said the LORD is a jealous God who will not forgive transgressions or sins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua states that the LORD is a holy and jealous God who will not forgive transgressions or sins in Joshua 24:19.

questions.question: True or False: The people refused to serve the LORD after Joshua’s warning.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The people said they would serve the LORD, refusing to forsake Him as recorded in Joshua 24:16 and 24:21.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua made a covenant with the people and set statutes in Shechem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua made a covenant with the people and set statutes and ordinances in Shechem according to Joshua 24:25.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Joshua 24:26: 'And Joshua wrote these words in the book of the law of God, and took a great _______, and set it up there under an oak.'
options: stone
tree
scroll
altar
questions.correctAnswer: stone
questions.explanation: Joshua took a great stone and set it up under an oak as a witness, as stated in Joshua 24:26.

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 24 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 24 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Joshua 24 teach us about the importance of choosing whom we will serve in our daily lives?
options: We must decide today whom we will serve: the LORD or other gods
We should serve all gods equally
It is best to avoid making a choice about service
Serving gods of our ancestors is always right
questions.correctAnswer: We must decide today whom we will serve: the LORD or other gods
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:15 emphasizes the necessity of making a clear decision to serve the LORD rather than other gods, teaching the importance of commitment and faithfulness in daily life. This is supported by verses 14, 20, and 24 which call for sincere service and warn against forsaking God.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation to follow old habits or worldly influences. Based on Joshua 24, what biblical truth would you share about overcoming this struggle?
options: Put away strange gods and serve the LORD with sincerity and truth
Ignore the struggle until it passes
Follow the traditions of your ancestors no matter what
Serve multiple gods to cover all bases
questions.correctAnswer: Put away strange gods and serve the LORD with sincerity and truth
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:14 and 23 instruct believers to put away foreign gods and serve the LORD faithfully and sincerely, showing that overcoming temptation requires wholehearted devotion and removing influences contrary to God’s will. Verses 19-20 warn of consequences for forsaking God.

questions.question: What does Joshua 24 teach about God's faithfulness in leading and providing for His people?
options: God led Abraham, brought Israel out of Egypt, and gave them the land they did not labor for
God only helps those who fight with their own strength
God abandoned Israel during their wilderness journey
God gave the land after the people worked hard to build cities
questions.correctAnswer: God led Abraham, brought Israel out of Egypt, and gave them the land they did not labor for
questions.explanation: Verses 3-7 and 13 explain God's faithful guidance from Abraham to the wilderness and into the land, providing blessings and possessions without Israel laboring for them, demonstrating His grace and provision. Verse 31 confirms Israel served the LORD all their days because of His works.

questions.question: How does Joshua 24 encourage believers to maintain integrity in their spiritual commitments?
options: By making a covenant and being witnesses to their choice to serve the LORD
By casually following God when convenient
By serving gods of other nations alongside the LORD
By avoiding making any formal promises
questions.correctAnswer: By making a covenant and being witnesses to their choice to serve the LORD
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:22-25 shows the importance of formal commitment through covenant and public witness, encouraging integrity and accountability in serving God. The setting up of a stone as a witness (verse 27) underlines the seriousness of their vow.

questions.question: A believer faces discouragement in their work because they see no immediate reward. What encouragement does Joshua 24 provide regarding God’s provision?
options: God gives a land and cities which the people did not build, and fruits they did not plant
Only hard work without God’s blessing leads to success
God expects believers to earn everything by their own effort
Rewards come only after many years of waiting
questions.correctAnswer: God gives a land and cities which the people did not build, and fruits they did not plant
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:13 reminds believers that God provides blessings beyond their labor, teaching contentment and trust in God's provision. This encourages believers to rely on God’s grace alongside their efforts.

questions.question: What warning does Joshua 24 give about serving the LORD with hypocrisy or half-heartedness?
options: You cannot serve the LORD because He is holy and jealous and will not forgive sins lightly
The LORD will accept any kind of service
Serving strange gods brings no consequences
God ignores transgressions if you serve Him sometimes
questions.correctAnswer: You cannot serve the LORD because He is holy and jealous and will not forgive sins lightly
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:19 warns that the LORD is holy and jealous, and He will not forgive transgressions easily, emphasizing sincere, wholehearted service and obedience. Verses 20 and 14 reinforce this call for purity in devotion.

questions.question: How does the chapter illustrate the role of prayer and dependence on God during trials?
options: When Israel cried to the LORD, He intervened by defeating the Egyptians and enemies
Israel defeated enemies by their own strength without God’s help
Prayer had no impact on Israel’s battles
God allowed Israel to fail so they would learn
questions.correctAnswer: When Israel cried to the LORD, He intervened by defeating the Egyptians and enemies
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:7 and 10 describe how God responded to Israel’s cries by putting darkness between them and the Egyptians and blessing them instead of cursing, demonstrating the power of prayer and dependence on God in trials.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 24 teaches that family leadership includes committing to serve the LORD together.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:15 shows Joshua’s declaration, 'as for me and my house, we will serve the LORD,' illustrating the biblical principle of family leadership in spiritual commitment.

questions.question: True or False: The people of Israel expressed willingness to forsake the LORD and serve other gods according to Joshua 24.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:16 and 21 record the people's response rejecting forsaking the LORD and affirming their commitment to serve Him, demonstrating loyalty and obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Joshua set up a great stone under an oak as a __________ to the people's covenant with God.
options: witness
monument
sacrifice
temple
questions.correctAnswer: witness
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:26-27 explains that the stone was set up as a witness to the covenant and the words spoken by God, serving as a reminder of their commitment.

questions.question: How does Joshua 24 instruct believers regarding idols and past practices of their ancestors?
options: Put away the gods which your fathers served on the other side of the flood and in Egypt
Honor and continue the gods of your ancestors
Ignore the gods your fathers served
Worship both the LORD and other gods to be safe
questions.correctAnswer: Put away the gods which your fathers served on the other side of the flood and in Egypt
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:14 calls for putting away the gods served by their ancestors, emphasizing repentance and exclusive devotion to the LORD for true obedience and blessing.

questions.question: What lesson about God’s justice and mercy can we learn from Joshua 24’s recounting of Balaam’s story?
options: God rejected Balaam’s curses and instead blessed Israel, showing His protective mercy
God allowed Balaam to curse Israel as he wished
Balaam’s blessings were ineffective
Israel defeated Balaam by their own power
questions.correctAnswer: God rejected Balaam’s curses and instead blessed Israel, showing His protective mercy
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:9-10 recounts how God would not listen to Balaam’s curses but blessed Israel, illustrating God’s justice and mercy in protecting His people despite external threats.

questions.question: Based on Joshua 24, what attitude should believers have toward God’s commands and statutes?
options: Obedient and willing to serve as a testimony to others
Disobedient but hopeful for forgiveness
Indifferent to laws and commands
Selective about obeying only convenient statutes
questions.correctAnswer: Obedient and willing to serve as a testimony to others
questions.explanation: Verses 24-25 and 22 show the people agreeing to serve God and obey His voice, and Joshua making a covenant, highlighting wholehearted obedience as a witness to others.

questions.question: How does Joshua 24 teach us about gratitude and contentment in God’s blessings?
options: Believers enjoy vineyards and oliveyards they did not plant, showing God’s generous provision
We must earn every blessing by our own labor
Gratitude is unnecessary when blessings are delayed
Contentment depends on worldly possessions only
questions.correctAnswer: Believers enjoy vineyards and oliveyards they did not plant, showing God’s generous provision
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:13 reminds believers that God gives blessings they did not labor for, encouraging gratitude and contentment in His generous provision.

questions.question: What does Joshua 24 reveal about the importance of spiritual leadership and legacy in a believer's life?
options: Joshua served the LORD throughout his life and influenced elders who knew God’s works
Leaders have no influence on others' faith
Spiritual leadership is only temporary and unimportant
Legacy does not affect future generations
questions.correctAnswer: Joshua served the LORD throughout his life and influenced elders who knew God’s works
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:31 shows that Israel served the LORD all their days and during the days of elders who knew God’s works, highlighting faithful leadership’s role in spiritual legacy.

questions.question: How does Joshua 24 encourage believers to be witnesses in their faith commitments?
options: By publicly declaring their choice to serve the LORD and making covenant
By keeping faith private and secret
By mixing faith with other gods
By ignoring commitments altogether
questions.correctAnswer: By publicly declaring their choice to serve the LORD and making covenant
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:22-27 shows the people publicly witnessing their choice to serve the LORD and Joshua setting up a stone as a witness, teaching the importance of public testimony and accountability.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 24 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 24.

questions.question: In Joshua 24:15, Joshua challenges the people to choose whom they will serve. Which two groups of gods does he specifically mention for them to choose between?
options: The gods which your fathers served on the other side of the flood and the gods of the Amorites
The gods of Egypt and the gods of Babylon
The gods of the Canaanites and the gods of the Philistines
The gods of the wilderness and the gods of the sea
questions.correctAnswer: The gods which your fathers served on the other side of the flood and the gods of the Amorites
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:15 explicitly mentions these two groups of gods to highlight the choice Israel faces between their ancestral gods and the local Canaanite gods.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily employed in Joshua 24:1-28, where Joshua recounts Israel's history and calls for a covenant renewal?
options: Chiasm
Parable
Allegory
Typology
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The passage shows a chiastic structure where Joshua's historical review (A) frames the covenant renewal (B), then returns to the historical summary (A'), emphasizing the covenantal decision at the center.

questions.question: Joshua 24:19 describes God as a 'jealous God.' What is the significance of the Hebrew term 'qanna' (jealous) in this context?
options: It emphasizes God's exclusive claim to Israel's worship and covenant loyalty
It means God is envious of other gods
It indicates God’s anger towards idolatry without mercy
It reflects God’s indifference to Israel’s sins
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's exclusive claim to Israel's worship and covenant loyalty
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'qanna' conveys God's zeal for exclusive worship, highlighting His demand for Israel’s faithfulness as seen in Joshua 24:19.

questions.question: How does Joshua 24:3-4 connect to the Abrahamic covenant found in Genesis 12 and 15?
options: By recounting God’s promise to Abraham to multiply his seed and give land to his descendants
By describing the exodus from Egypt
By detailing the Ten Commandments
By explaining the construction of the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: By recounting God’s promise to Abraham to multiply his seed and give land to his descendants
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:3-4 echoes the covenant promises to Abraham in Genesis, affirming land and descendants as central themes.

questions.question: Which historical-cultural context is reflected in Joshua 24:9-10 where Balak and Balaam are mentioned?
options: Relations and conflicts between Israel and Moab during the wilderness wanderings
Egyptian oppression of Israel
Philistine wars during the period of the judges
Babylonian exile
questions.correctAnswer: Relations and conflicts between Israel and Moab during the wilderness wanderings
questions.explanation: The reference to Balak and Balaam recalls Numbers 22-24, illustrating Moabite opposition to Israel in the wilderness era.

questions.question: In Joshua 24:12, God is said to have sent hornets before Israel. This is an example of what type of divine intervention in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Natural agents used as instruments of God’s judgment and deliverance
Angelic armies
Miraculous earthquakes
Direct human warfare
questions.correctAnswer: Natural agents used as instruments of God’s judgment and deliverance
questions.explanation: The sending of hornets signifies God’s use of natural creatures to drive out enemies, a known motif in ancient warfare and divine assistance (Joshua 24:12).

questions.question: How does Joshua 24:26 use a stone as a literary and cultural symbol within the covenant renewal ceremony?
options: As a witness to the covenant and a memorial to God’s words, anchoring the event in physical reality
As a weapon to defend the people
As a symbol of the temple’s foundation
As a symbol of the promised land’s fertility
questions.correctAnswer: As a witness to the covenant and a memorial to God’s words, anchoring the event in physical reality
questions.explanation: The stone set up by Joshua serves as a tangible witness to the covenant, a common ancient Near Eastern practice (Joshua 24:26-27).

questions.question: What typological significance does Joshua’s death at age 110 (Joshua 24:29) have in relation to Moses’ life span?
options: It symbolizes the completion of an era, as Moses also died at 120 after leading Israel to the edge of the promised land
It indicates failure to enter the promised land
It shows Joshua’s youth compared to Moses
It points to the beginning of the monarchy
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the completion of an era, as Moses also died at 120 after leading Israel to the edge of the promised land
questions.explanation: Joshua’s death marks the end of Israel’s wilderness leadership, paralleling Moses’ death, both significant transitions (Joshua 24:29).

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 24:31, Israel served the LORD only during Joshua’s lifetime and ceased afterward.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:31 states Israel served the LORD all the days of Joshua and the elders who outlived him, indicating continued faithfulness beyond Joshua’s life.

questions.question: Which intertextual connection does Joshua 24:32 make by mentioning the burial of Joseph's bones at Shechem?
options: It connects to Genesis 50:25 and Exodus 13:19 where Joseph’s bones were taken out of Egypt
It references the Exodus command to build altars
It alludes to David’s burial place in Jerusalem
It signifies the building of Solomon’s temple
questions.correctAnswer: It connects to Genesis 50:25 and Exodus 13:19 where Joseph’s bones were taken out of Egypt
questions.explanation: The burial of Joseph’s bones in Shechem recalls the patriarchal promises and the Exodus narratives (Joshua 24:32).

questions.question: Joshua 24:14 exhorts Israel to 'fear the LORD, and serve him in sincerity and in truth.' How does this call relate to the Deuteronomic covenant theology?
options: It echoes Deuteronomy’s emphasis on exclusive loyalty and heartfelt obedience to God
It introduces a new covenant unrelated to Deuteronomy
It focuses on ritual sacrifices exclusively
It contradicts earlier covenant commands
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes Deuteronomy’s emphasis on exclusive loyalty and heartfelt obedience to God
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:14 reflects Deuteronomistic themes of covenant faithfulness and wholehearted service found in Deuteronomy 6 and 10.

questions.question: In the historical context of Joshua 24:6-7, what is the significance of God putting darkness between Israel and the Egyptians at the Red Sea?
options: It demonstrates God’s protective power and miraculous deliverance during the Exodus
It indicates a natural sandstorm
It refers to a military alliance with other nations
It describes a solar eclipse
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God’s protective power and miraculous deliverance during the Exodus
questions.explanation: The divine darkness is a miraculous act protecting Israel from Egyptian pursuit, highlighting God’s intervention (Joshua 24:7).

questions.question: Joshua 24:23 commands to 'put away the strange gods which are among you.' How does this command relate to the broader biblical theme of idolatry?
options: It reinforces the biblical prohibition against idolatry as betrayal of the covenant with Yahweh
It permits syncretism with foreign gods
It focuses on social customs rather than worship
It suggests idolatry is acceptable in times of crisis
questions.correctAnswer: It reinforces the biblical prohibition against idolatry as betrayal of the covenant with Yahweh
questions.explanation: The command is consistent with the Torah’s strict injunctions against idolatry, emphasizing covenant purity (Joshua 24:23).

questions.question: What is the significance of the covenant ceremony taking place at Shechem as recorded in Joshua 24:1 and 25?
options: Shechem was a traditional covenant site linking Abrahamic promises to Israel’s present
It was the capital city of Israel
It was the location of the tabernacle
It was a Philistine stronghold
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem was a traditional covenant site linking Abrahamic promises to Israel’s present
questions.explanation: Shechem was historically significant as a place Abraham purchased (Genesis 12:6-7), making it fitting for covenant renewal (Joshua 24:1,25).

questions.question: According to Joshua 24:20, what consequence does God warn will happen if Israel forsakes Him and serves strange gods?
options: God will turn and do them hurt and consume them after having done them good
They will be blessed with prosperity
They will be given peace with neighboring nations
They will receive immediate forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: God will turn and do them hurt and consume them after having done them good
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:20 warns of divine judgment and reversal of blessings if Israel abandons the LORD for other gods.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 24:16-18 is an example of Israel’s corporate confession and recognition of God’s acts in their history.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The people’s response in Joshua 24:16-18 acknowledges God’s deliverance and faithfulness, serving as a communal confession of faith.

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 24 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 24 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason Joshua calls all the tribes of Israel to Shechem in Joshua 24?
options: To renew the covenant and call the people to serve the LORD sincerely
To appoint new judges and officers over Israel
To distribute the land among the tribes
To celebrate a festival to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: To renew the covenant and call the people to serve the LORD sincerely
questions.explanation: Joshua gathers the tribes to Shechem to remind them of God's faithfulness and to command them to serve the LORD sincerely and truthfully (Joshua 24:1, 14). This covenant renewal echoes covenant calls in Deuteronomy 29:10-15 and 2 Chronicles 15:8, emphasizing wholehearted commitment to God.

questions.question: According to Joshua 24, what distinguished God’s covenant with Abraham from the gods served by Abraham’s ancestors?
options: God took Abraham from other gods and led him to a promised land
God allowed Abraham to serve many gods
God ignored Abraham’s ancestors’ gods
God changed Abraham’s name without any promise
questions.correctAnswer: God took Abraham from other gods and led him to a promised land
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:2-3 explains God’s unique act of taking Abraham from other gods and leading him through Canaan, promising land and descendants. This reflects God's sovereign election and covenant faithfulness (cf. Genesis 12:1-3; Acts 7:2-5).

questions.question: How does Joshua describe God’s holiness and jealousy in relation to the people's ability to serve Him?
options: God is holy and jealous and will not forgive transgressions if they serve other gods
God is indifferent to their worship practices
God is forgiving regardless of worship
God allows serving multiple gods
questions.correctAnswer: God is holy and jealous and will not forgive transgressions if they serve other gods
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:19 states that God is holy and jealous, meaning He demands exclusive worship and will not forgive those who turn to other gods. This aligns with Old Testament teaching on God's holiness (Leviticus 19:2) and New Testament affirmations of God's jealousy (2 Corinthians 11:2).

questions.question: What consequence does Joshua warn will come if Israel forsakes the LORD and serves strange gods?
options: God will turn and do them hurt, consuming them after doing them good
God will be indifferent
God will immediately destroy them
God will bless their enemies but not punish them
questions.correctAnswer: God will turn and do them hurt, consuming them after doing them good
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:20 warns that forsaking God results in judgment, specifically that God will harm those who abandon Him after He has blessed them. This reflects the covenant blessings and curses principle (Deuteronomy 28:15-68) and God's righteous judgment theme (Hebrews 10:26-31).

questions.question: In Joshua 24, how does God demonstrate His saving power and faithfulness to Israel's ancestors?
options: By bringing them out of Egypt, delivering them from enemies, and giving them land
By letting them conquer lands without His help
By allowing them to worship other gods
By remaining silent during their hardships
questions.correctAnswer: By bringing them out of Egypt, delivering them from enemies, and giving them land
questions.explanation: Verses 5-13 recount God's mighty acts: delivering Israel from Egypt, defeating enemies like the Amorites, and giving them land they did not labor for. This displays God’s sovereignty and covenant fulfillment (Exodus 12:31-42; Deuteronomy 7:1-2).

questions.question: Which statement best summarizes Joshua’s famous declaration about whom he and his house will serve?
options: "As for me and my house, we will serve the LORD"
"We will serve the gods of our ancestors"
"We will serve the gods of the Amorites"
"We will serve whichever god prospers us"
questions.correctAnswer: "As for me and my house, we will serve the LORD"
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:15 declares his resolute commitment to serve the LORD exclusively, setting an example of faithful leadership, which is echoed in Christian teaching on household faithfulness (1 Timothy 3:4-5).

questions.question: What is the significance of the stone that Joshua sets up under the oak at Shechem?
options: It serves as a witness to the covenant between God and Israel
It marks a burial site
It is an idol for the people to worship
It represents worldly power
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a witness to the covenant between God and Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:26-27 explains the stone is a covenant witness, reminding Israel of their commitment to God. This practice resembles covenant stones in the Old Testament (Deuteronomy 27:2-8) and the biblical emphasis on tangible reminders of God's promises (Exodus 24:12-18).

questions.question: How do the people respond when Joshua asks if they will forsake the LORD to serve other gods?
options: They firmly reject the idea and commit to serving the LORD
They hesitate and refuse to answer
They say they will serve other gods
They ask for more time to decide
questions.correctAnswer: They firmly reject the idea and commit to serving the LORD
questions.explanation: In Joshua 24:16 and 21, the people decisively reject forsaking the LORD and pledge to serve Him. This reflects the covenant renewal pattern and the call for exclusive loyalty to God (Deuteronomy 6:4-5).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by God giving Israel a land and cities they did not build, and eating from vineyards they did not plant?
options: God’s sovereign grace in providing blessings apart from human merit
Human effort is the basis for blessing
Blessings come only from conquest by sword
Israel earned the land by their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign grace in providing blessings apart from human merit
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:13 highlights God’s grace in giving Israel land and sustenance they did not labor for, underscoring salvation and blessing as acts of divine grace rather than human works (cf. Ephesians 2:8-9; Deuteronomy 7:7-8).

questions.question: Who are the two sons given to Isaac by God, and what land was assigned to the elder according to Joshua 24?
options: Jacob and Esau; Esau was given Mount Seir
Esau and Ishmael; Ishmael was given Mount Seir
Jacob and Joseph; Joseph was given Mount Seir
Jacob and Esau; Jacob was given Mount Seir
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob and Esau; Esau was given Mount Seir
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:4 states God gave Isaac Jacob and Esau; Esau was assigned Mount Seir, while Jacob and his children went to Egypt. This shows God’s sovereign distribution of land and covenant promises (Genesis 36:8).

questions.question: What role did Balak and Balaam play in Israel’s history as described in Joshua 24?
options: Balak tried to curse Israel through Balaam, but Balaam blessed them instead
Balak helped Israel defeat their enemies
Balaam led Israel into idolatry
Balak and Balaam were judges of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Balak tried to curse Israel through Balaam, but Balaam blessed them instead
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:9-10 recounts how Balak hired Balaam to curse Israel, but God prevented curses and caused blessings instead. This illustrates God’s protective sovereignty (Numbers 22-24; 2 Peter 2:15).

questions.question: According to Joshua 24, why is it impossible for the people to truly serve the LORD without wholehearted commitment?
options: Because the LORD is holy and jealous and will not tolerate divided loyalty
Because the LORD is indifferent
Because the LORD allows multiple gods to be served
Because the LORD’s commands are unclear
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is holy and jealous and will not tolerate divided loyalty
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:19 teaches that the LORD’s holiness and jealousy demand exclusive worship; divided loyalty is incompatible with serving God. This theme aligns with the Shema (Deuteronomy 6:4-5) and New Testament calls for undivided devotion (James 4:4).

questions.question: What does Joshua instruct the people to do with the 'strange gods' among them after they renew their covenant with the LORD?
options: Put them away and incline their hearts to the LORD God of Israel
Keep them for good luck
Worship them alongside the LORD
Hide them secretly
questions.correctAnswer: Put them away and incline their hearts to the LORD God of Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:23 commands Israel to remove foreign gods and sincerely turn their hearts to God, emphasizing repentance and exclusive devotion (cf. Exodus 20:3; 2 Chronicles 15:8).

questions.question: What does the statement 'Ye are witnesses against yourselves that ye have chosen you the LORD, to serve him' signify about Israel’s covenant renewal?
options: The people are consciously affirming their covenant commitment before God
The people are being forced against their will
The people are unsure about serving the LORD
The people are rejecting the covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The people are consciously affirming their covenant commitment before God
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:22 shows the covenant renewal is a deliberate, public affirmation with the people acknowledging their choice to serve God, highlighting human responsibility in covenant faithfulness (Deuteronomy 30:19; Hebrews 8:6).

questions.question: How does Joshua 24 portray the relationship between God’s past acts of salvation and Israel’s present duty?
options: God’s mighty deeds obligate Israel to fear and serve Him sincerely
God’s past acts have no bearing on present obedience
Israel’s duty is independent of God’s acts
God’s acts allow Israel to serve other gods as well
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mighty deeds obligate Israel to fear and serve Him sincerely
questions.explanation: Joshua 24 links God’s historical deliverance (verses 5-13) with the call to fear and serve Him sincerely (verse 14), showing covenant faithfulness is a response to divine grace (Psalm 78:7; Romans 12:1).

questions.question: What does the burial of Joseph’s bones in Shechem symbolize in the theological narrative of Joshua 24?
options: The fulfillment of God’s promise to bring Israel back to the Promised Land
The end of Joseph’s story without significance
A political claim over Shechem only
A break from ancestral promises
questions.correctAnswer: The fulfillment of God’s promise to bring Israel back to the Promised Land
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:32 recounts Joseph’s bones being buried in Shechem, symbolizing God’s faithfulness in fulfilling His promise to Israel to bring them back to their land (cf. Genesis 50:24-25; Hebrews 11:22).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'the LORD our God will we serve, and his voice will we obey' indicate about Israel’s ecclesiology in Joshua 24?
options: It reflects Israel’s covenant community commitment to obedience and worship under God’s rule
It means they will serve many gods equally
It shows Israel’s rejection of God’s authority
It refers only to ritual practices without heart commitment
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects Israel’s covenant community commitment to obedience and worship under God’s rule
questions.explanation: Joshua 24:24 emphasizes the corporate nature of Israel’s commitment to worship and obey God, foundational for biblical ecclesiology emphasizing covenant community under God’s lordship (Exodus 19:5-6; Acts 2:42-47).
